newsitem.title: USA: US House rejects $60 per ton cut in peanut support.
newsitem.headline: US House rejects $60 per ton cut in peanut support.

text.p: The U.S. House turned down a proposal to reduce the peanut support price by $60 per ton to $550 per ton, as a step toward eliminating the program.
Representatives rejected the amendment, 185-222, while working on the fiscal 1998 agriculture appropriations bill.
New York Democrat Nita Lowey said Americans paid an extra 30 cents for an 18-ounce jar of peanut butter because U.S. prices were double the world rate. "That's not peanuts," she said.

Farm-state lawmakers said the idea of lower food costs was illusory because peanuts were only a small factor in the price of food. They also appealed to colleagues to stick by the reforms of the 1996 farm policy law, which cut the support price by 10 percent to $610 per ton and froze it.
"We did reform, contrary to what was said," said Eva Clayton.
Wisconsin Republican Mark Neumann said it was time to end the peanut program with its system of awarding production quotas to farmers.
